Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: the Acquisition of Tone in a Second Language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Much research over the past several decades has been dedicated to studying the challenges and successes of learning an additional language beyond one's native tongue. However, this body of research has focused on just a handful of well-known Indo-European and East Asian languages, which account for less than 1% of the world's 6-7,000 languages. A consequence is that little is known about the acquisition of many linguistic features. One such feature is tone, the use of pitch to distinguish words. This gap is especially unfortunate given that over half of the world's languages are tone languages, and that second language speakers of tone languages are increasing in number, both in the U.S. (as more people choose to study Mandarin Chinese, for instance) and worldwide, often due to language revitalization efforts in parts of the world where tone languages abound. In both contexts, second language speakers often struggle to produce and perceive tone, even when they are otherwise considered to be competent speakers of the language. New research is needed in order to uncover the differences and difficulties involved in acquiring tones.

As a case study, this dissertation examines the acquisition of tone among adolescents learning Sierra Juarez Zapotec, an endangered language traditionally spoken in San Pablo Macuiltianguis (Oaxaca, Mexico). The learners are native Spanish speakers studying Zapotec as a second language through a language revitalization program. Six months of video and audio-recorded Zapotec classroom data will be transcribed and analyzed in order to examine tone learning over time. This approach allows current theories of second language acquisition to be evaluated. In particular, the study tests a frequency-driven theory of second language acquisition: the claim that the more frequently a learner is exposed to a linguistic feature, the easier that feature will be to learn. It also explores factors that mediate this frequency effect when it comes to tone learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported doctoral dissertation research that investigated tone acquisition among children learning Sierra Juarez Zapotec (an endangered language of Oaxaca, Mexico) through a language revitalization program. As part of this research, the awardee created a searchable, multilayer, multimedia (video, audio, text) corpus (i.e., database) of teacher talk and student production collected from the Zapotec classroom over a period of ten months.

Intellectual merit:

Although over half of the world’s languages are tonal, studies of tone learning in second or later-acquired languages are scarce and limited to a handful of socio-politically dominant tone languages spoken in east and southeast Asia. Indigenous communities in the Americas who speak a tone language and wish to revitalize their language through teaching therefore have little information about how tone learning can be expected to proceed. Studies of L2 tone learning in Mandarin, Cantonese, and Thai suggest that learners of tone languages do not perceive and produce the different tones of the target language with equal ease. The most common explanation for these asymmetries is that acoustically salient tones are the easiest to learn. An alternative explanation offered in the literature is that tones are easiest to learn when they are highly frequent in the input. The characteristics of Sierra Juárez Zapotec provided the conditions for a study that pitted the acoustic salience hypothesis against the input frequency hypothesis.

The dissertation showed that Zapotec learners, like other learners of tone languages, demonstrated asymmetries in how well they produce and perceive the different tones of the target language. This suggests that there may be certain, possibly universal, cognitive mechanisms at work that make some tones easier to learn than others. The findings further showed that acoustic salience, tone frequency, and relative word frequency all predicted tone production accuracy, confirming the suggestions in the literature that these factors interact to influence L2 tone acquisition. This finding lends support to usage-based approaches to language learning in which frequency interacts with other input factors such as salience to predict a single learning outcome. However, the results also showed that input frequency drove tone learning productivity while acoustic salience helped learners accurately map tone patterns to lexical items. This suggests that existing usage-based models may need to be modified in a way that associates frequency and salience with distinct learning outcomes (i.e., frequency with productivity-type learning outcomes and salience with mapping-type learning outcomes).

Broader impacts:

This project has had direct implications for the Zapotec community where the study took place. The research project made more visible the value of the traditional language within the community. The project provided new opportunities for reading and writing the language through the creation of classroom materials as well as transcriptions of recordings for the corpus, which in turn became a useful resource in the creation of Zapotec teaching materials. The presence of a linguist in the community provided training opportunities for language activists and Zapotec language teachers. Instructors gained training in effective language teaching methods as well as a better understanding of the types of errors students make and how they are expected to develop. It also presented opportunities for workshops on linguistic topics such as the characteristics of the tone system of the language. Armed with such knowledge, language activists are better prepared to read and write in the language, to defend their writing system against critics, and to conduct their own linguistic investigations.

The project has provided the awardee with opportunities to improve her research skills in the areas of language documentation, phonetic analysis, and database/corpus building. It provided a platform to deepen personal and professional relationships in the community and the region that will be critical for conducting similar research in the future.
